01-01: This day marks the beginning of the new calendar year. It is traditionally associated with fresh starts, resolutions and celebrations. In the United Kingdom it is a public holiday and most businesses are closed.
04-18: Good Friday commemorates the crucifixion of Jesus Christ and is a key day in the Christian calendar. It is observed with religious services and quiet reflection. In the UK it is a public holiday.
05-05: May Day is associated with the celebration of workers' rights and the arrival of spring. Its origins are linked to labour movements and traditional seasonal festivals. It is observed as a public holiday in the United Kingdom.
05-26: The Spring Bank Holiday provides a break at the end of May. It is not tied to a specific historical event but serves as a national day of rest. Many people use it for travel or outdoor activities.
12-25: Christmas Day celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ and is one of the most important holidays in the UK. It is traditionally spent with family, exchanging gifts and sharing festive meals. It is a public holiday nationwide.
12-26: Boxing Day follows Christmas Day and has historical roots in giving gifts to workers and the poor. Today it is associated with leisure, shopping and sporting events. It is a public holiday in the United Kingdom.
